content: The "Public Domain Enhancement Act" is the short title of the Act. It includes findings related to the public domain. The Congress finds that the copyright clause in the US Constitution grants Congress the power to promote the progress of science and arts by securing exclusive rights to authors for limited times. This serves to provide economic incentives for authors to create new works and promotes society's interest in the free flow of ideas and commerce. The copyright clause in the US Constitution grants Congress the power to promote the progress of science and arts by securing exclusive rights to authors for limited times. This serves to provide economic incentives for authors to create new works and promotes society's interest in the free flow of ideas and commerce. The copyright term is limited so that the public will not be permanently deprived of the fruits of an artist's labors. Both commercial and noncommercial creators depend on a healthy public domain for various purposes. Public domain works are used for various purposes such as creating new productions, educational materials, and historical content on the World Wide Web. Current copyright law protects works published as early as 1923, but the majority of older works are no longer commercially viable. Under current copyright law, works published as early as 1923 are protected, but the majority of older works are no longer commercially available. Only 2 percent of works between 55 and 75 years old retain commercial value. Despite this, abandoned works will not enter the public domain for many years, hindering entities from building upon them. Older works may not have commercial value but can be useful for historians, artists, and teachers. The existing copyright system does not align with the original intent of the Constitution and the Copyright Act, as it hinders the public from accessing abandoned works that hold historical and educational value. It is necessary to establish a mechanism for abandoned American copyrights to enter the public domain. SEC. 3. MAINTENANCE FEE FOR PUBLISHED UNITED STATES WORKS. The definition of "United States work" in section 101 of title 17, United States Code, is amended for sections 306 and 411. Section 302 of title 17 is amended for works created on or after January 1, 1978, regarding the duration of copyright. The amendments to sections 303 and 304 of title 17, United States Code, involve changes related to copyright protection for works created before January 1, 1978. These changes include inserting references to section 306 and clarifying conditions for copyright protection. Amendments to section 304 of title 17, United States Code, involve changes to copyright protection for works created before January 1, 1978. This includes inserting references to section 306 and clarifying conditions for copyright protection. Amendments to section 304 of title 17, United States Code involve inserting references to section 306 for copyright protection of works created before January 1, 1978. This includes adding a maintenance fee of $1 for published United States works. The Register of Copyrights will charge a $1 maintenance fee for published United States works to keep the copyright in force. The fee is due 50 years after first publication or on December 31, 2004, and every 10 years thereafter. Failure to pay the fee within a 6-month grace period will result in the copyright expiring. The copyright maintenance fee is required to keep the copyright in force for published United States works. Failure to pay the fee within a 6-month grace period will result in the copyright expiring. Ancillary and promotional works connected to the maintained work will also be kept in force. The fee must be accompanied by a prescribed form and additional material as required by the Register of Copyrights. The maintenance fee for published United States works is required to keep the copyright in force. The fee must be paid within a 6-month grace period to prevent the copyright from expiring. Additionally, ancillary and promotional works related to the maintained work will also be kept in force. The fee must be submitted with a prescribed form and any additional material requested by the Register of Copyrights. The Register of Copyrights must establish procedures within 12 months to ease the submission of forms and make the information easily accessible to the public under section 306(c) of title 17, United States Code.
